title: Bobby Lord - Everybodys Rockin' But Me - 1954-1960
description:
Bobby Lord - Everybodys Rockin' But Me : Gonna Shake This Shack Tonight

Bear Family CD. Release: 2011.

Bobby Lord slipped through the cracks. No More!,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œHawk-Eye,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œEverybodyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s RockinÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ But MeÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ -- failed to launch, Lord dabbled in all the sounds of the times, going for teeny-bopper ballads, bobby-sox 2-steps, and historical fables straight out of Johnny Horton's playbook. Lord handled these turns capably, even impressively, throwing himself into the sounds even when they didnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t deserve much energy, which they certainly didnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t when he had to sing dance-hop fluff like ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œParty Pooper.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ Such sickly sweet pop tunes weigh down Bear Family's comp to an extent -- particularly when theyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢re included in favor of actual charting country singles like ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œWithout Your LoveÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ -- but taken from another angle, EverybodyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s RockinÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ But Me is a pretty fun snapshot of what it meant to be a singer on the make in the back end of the '50s: you needed to try everything to get anywhere, and Lord certainly did. He was good enough to make the twists in fashion credible and fortunate to cut a handful of terrific little cult items that are strong enough to make this whole disc worth investigating.
